This is a very nice game about the American 82nd and 101st Airborne divisions of WWII. The spawning system involves jumping about of a plane and parachuting down on your enemies, which is rather exciting. Another thing worthy of note is that during the campaign, you face Tiger I tanks. You know, the killing machines that were feared by Sherman tanks everywhere. These monsters are not at all unwilling to lob their 88mm HE rounds directly at your face, which, quite fittingly, is an insta-kill. The only way to retaliate against them is with Gammon grenades or an AT Rifle.  The choice of weapons is also pleasing, and their roles in combat are well-shown. As in, machine guns are deadly to both you and your foe, and sniping with any old weapon simply won't work. Grenades also show their role both as a surpression weapon and a room-clearing device.  One of the better brand-name first-person shooters that has a surprisingly high amount of realism, definately look into this one.

I grew up playing Call of Duty (2003) , United Offensive (2004), and Call of Duty 2 (2005). I recently bought the original Medal of Honor (1999), Allied Assault (2002), and this game (2007) to see what I was missing out on, and to compare them to Call of Duty's franchise, game-to-game based on release year. Medal of Honor has no comparison due to it's release year so I'll leave it be, but Allied Assault is ♥♥♥♥ compared to Call of Duty and United Offensive. However, I think Airborne beats Call of Duty 2 as far as the gameplay, controls, and story go. The medal awards like a strip clip for a Mauser are interesting and give the player something to strive for. The leaning is like Wolfenstein: The New Order (2014). While you're aiming down the sights (ADS), you can use WASD to lean left, right, up, and down. Hold Shift and you're able to walk around while ADS. The controls feel intuitive and the graphics hold up against Call of Duty 2.

A very interesting mechanic poorly executed.  Being able to jump out of a plane to land anywhere on the field is a neat idea. You can land on a roof and shoot your way down, or land behind the enemy and flank them.  And that’s about where the good ends.  The weapons have a neat level-up mechanic. The more you use a certain weapon, you will earn attachments for it, and make it better. Unfortunately, at the beginning of the game when you don’t have any proficiencies, the weapons are incredibly difficult to use. I remember having a rifle, looking down the sights at an enemy’s chest, and emptying entire magazines without a single hit. The inaccuracy of the weapons in this game can make it very frustrating.  The enemies scale, and get more difficult as you progress. That’s good. The highest level enemies, though, are laughable and unrealistic. Also, after five legitimate missions, the sixth and final mission feels like a giant spoof of the entire game.  Lastly, the game’s big gimmick is parachuting to any place on the battlefield. I never once learned how to land correctly. The instructions were not very clear, and after failing all three times in the tutorial, I was approved and sent off to war. I played every mission, and made countless landings, and botched every single one. I was upset that I couldn’t do it, but even more upset that I couldn’t LEARN to do it.  This game was a novelty when I was looking for something I hadn’t played before, but it’s not something I’ll ever go back to with fond memories.

I am a pretty big fan of the good ol' Medal of Honor series, but as much as it hurts to say this, I can't really recommend this one. Yeah, I've played for mere minutes, but there's a reason for that. First off, upon my first start up of the game, I was waiting ever so patiently for it to install all the useless stuff, only for it to tell me that my graphics card is not supported. Now, because I have an Intel HD 4200, I can understand why this wouldn't work. Obviously, I wasn't gonna call it a day there. I looked around, searched the forums, the Googles, and found something called PhysX Legacy. Several places said installing this would make it work. Did that, no difference.  I then found someone saying to just rename the setup .exe in the games files, and upon doing that, the game actually started up.  And now, to the actual game itself.  Because the setup was renamed, the game kinda ignored all the graphical stuff, and does not allow me to mess with the graphics settings. When playing a cutscene, most, if not all the characters are simply black silhouettes. I was watching as one of them was showing me my objective in a town in Italy, which just turned out to be a blank wall. So, if you end up like I did where your card is not suppoted, you can't do much about the cutscenes.  Now, the gameplay. The first mission, and probably every single other mission, starts out with you jumping out of a plane. You parachute into the town, your objective to take out AA and artillery guns. Now, this is just my opinion, but I didn't like the fact that it didn't matter what order I completed my objectives. I found myself running through the empty streets, from one side of the town to the other, all of a sudden running into some firefight close to the objective. I've played Allied Assault, European Assault, Rising Sun, Vanguard, and the missions were all linear and not really picky. I think that's how it should have been with Airborne. The idea of choosing how to do the mission is cool, but something about the topic and the way it was executed just makes me think that it's not as good as it could be. In Vanguard, you did the same thing, jump, land, and one by one finish your job. In Airborne, you jump, and you can finish the mission as you please.  The shooting is a bit odd to me, but that's probably because I'm used to shooting without iron sights, like in the old MoHs. You can sprint, the health bar is different than just about every other MoH, giving you 4 bars that can regenerate with either health packs or just over time, so long as the bar is not empty. In Vanguard, it worked like CoD, get shot, wait a few, its like nothing happened. In the older ones, you had 100 health, and could only get more if you picked up bottles, medkits, etc.  I do not reccomend because the game is simply too much of a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get up and running, and if you have the problem I had, you will not be able to toy around with the graphic settings. Hell, there isn't even an option to do so, other than brightness and whatnot. The multiplayer is also a major disappointment, as there is only 10 or less people playing. Allied Assault has more players than this game, and that's a game from 2002. If you're concerned about the story of it, it's World War 2. Not your forte? Go back to your futuristic bolonga. Medal of Honor Airborne was probably amazing in its day, but in 2014, it only causes problems and disappointment.

I'm not a big fan of the FPS genre so I might just be wrong, but from what I've seen in this game, MOH:A isn't a very good game. There isn't much to the game in terms of story, and usually you'd expect more from the gameplay. But then the very clunky control scheme is what pretty much ruins the experience. You can't move at all while aiming, which can get really annoying and disadvantageous. I'm not saying you should be able to move as quickly and as freely as usual, but at least you should be able to inch around a bit to get a better position, angle, or whatever. And this probably wouldn't have been as frustrating if the muzzle-loading process of some of the rifles weren't so terribly long. And yes, I'm playing on Hard mode. Simply switching to a lower difficulty still doesn't cut it.  Another sort of nitpick I have with this game is that when you shoot at an enemy, there is very little if at all any realistic signs on the target if it's been hit. It could be anything, be it a moan, blood splatter or at least falling back a bit due to the impact of the bullet, or whatever. But here you only know you've hit an enemy when they die, apparently. This just makes no sense because ... seriously no human can endure getting shot without a wince and still keep shooting until they're down. That's just ridiculous.  Not a very good FPS overall to me personally. I don't know much about this genre, but certainly there are things that the Call of Duty series has been doing way better than this game even since its first installment.

Step into the boots of Boyd Travers, Private First Class of the “All-American” 82nd Airborne Division, and revolutionize the way the war is fought. From a rocky beginning in Sicily to war winning triumphs in the heart of Germany, fight the epic WWII battles that turned America’s first paratroopers into combat legends. Begin each mission from the air and behind enemy lines, then jump immediately into the action. On the ground, tackle objectives in any order across an expansive, free-roaming environment, using a wide variety of upgradeable weapons to your strategic advantage.

I recommend this game due the following facts,   - This game has a shotgun. Ka-boom! Chak-Chak! Repeat.  - A good weapon upgrade system with a nice slow-motion effect with every level-up.  - Great cinematic sequences with beutiful maps.  - As in all other Medal of Honor games, fantastic soundtrack.  - Low price, worth every penny.    The only negative thing about this game is that there is a clear feeling through out the game that this game is a typical game made to fit both a PC format but as well a console format (PS3, Xbox).   Still, a good and entertaining game!

The lighting is one of my favorite parts as well, on the night maps there are some really beautiful scenes.  Bottom line the game is a lot of fun and looks great but is very short. At $5 though its completely worth it. There's never anybody playing multiplayer anymore but when there was it was a lot of fun, in mission-based multiplayer matches players get to paradrop in to the match which was also awesome. I'd love to see multiplayer become active again..maybe some day..

Overall I give this game a 9/10, because there is some hassle with loading the game up, since it's a 32-bit only game, so here's a tutorial:  1. Go to launch options for this game in your Steam library and type in 'xadapterd10'. 2. Launch the game. 3. Ctrl+Alt+Delete to the desktop and you will see a message, in which you will click on 'OK'. 4. Go back into the game and it should load up!  Another solution for dedicated graphics users may be to install a certain legacy driver for PhysX, which you can find by looking at one of the many guides on the community hub.  Also keep in mind that the multiplayer is pretty much dead, but hey, the campaign is immersive and fun as hell, so like I said before, I give this game a 9/10.

Bit Sized Review  The Good: -WWII levels are varied and have interesting design -'Droping in' Mechanic makes it so you start each level (and each respawn when you die) by parachuting into it where you want to -Level design allows you to take on objectives however you want -Aiming allows you to lean around corners and cover -There are quite a few weapons, and getting kills with them automatically unlocks upgrades -Price is pretty low  The Bad: -Aiming down the sights causes you to stop and aim, takes some getting used to  -Single Player is only 4 hours long -Not a lot of replayability -Multiplayer is almost completely dead -Story line is very boiler plate, not that interesting -Graphics and enemy AI do show their age here   The Verdict: If you want some more WWII shooter action, you can do a lot worst than this. It is not a bad game and on sale it's actually worth the price just to jump in and kill half a day on. I would recommend it when it's on sale since the MP is pretty much dead however.
